newsitem.title: CANADA: Northern Telecom Q3 order input climbs.
newsitem.headline: Northern Telecom Q3 order input climbs.

text.p: Northern Telecom Ltd said on Tuesday its order input rose in the third quarter to US$3.09 billion from US$2.69 billion in the year-ago period.
The company attributed the order growth to gains in the United States, the Caribbean, Latin America and Europe over last year's levels.
Order input for the first nine months of 1996 rose to US$8.81 billion from US$7.25 billion in the first three quarters of 1995, Nortel said.
Revenues climbed to US$3.05 billion in the third quarter from year ago US$2.49 billion.

"We are pleased with our revenue and earnings performance for the quarter; but just as pleasing are recent announcements in fixed wireless access, in-building wireless and Internet solutions, with new customers," said president and chief executive Jean Monty in a statement.
"These are examples of Nortel continuing to expand its breadth of telecom network solutions to meet the needs of new customers in our industry," he added.
U.S. sales rose "substantially" in the quarter across all network businesses. There were also good gains in the Caribbean-Latin America area and in Europe and Asia Pacific.
Sales in Canada also increased over the prior year.

Selling, general and administrative costs were US$526 million, or 17.2 percent of sales, in the quarter, versus US$468 million, or 18.8 percent, a year ago. For the nine months, SG&A rose to US$1.51 billion from US$1.37 billion in the first nine months of 1995. The rise is due to an expected increase in investments in global markets and enterprise and wireless networks businesses.
Research and development spending in the quarter moved up to US$439 million, or 14.4 percent of sales, versus US$406 million, or 16.3 percent, the prior year.

In the first nine months of 1996, R&D expenses were US$1.29 billion, or 14.9 percent of revenues, up from US$1.13 billion, or 15.7 percent of revenues, in the same period of 1995. Nortel said this is due to its planned and ongoing investments in wireless, enterprise and broadband networks businesses.

"Looking forward, our current breadth of portfolio and continuing investment in international markets positions us well for our planned growth in a global industry demonstrating growth driven by de-regulation, globalization and advances in technology," Monty said.
"This provides opportunities for companies such as Nortel that can deliver total network solutions," he added.
